caseTitle: JANET NAAKARLEY AMEGATCHER VRS THE ATTORNEY-GENERAL, THE ELECTORAL COMMISSION
summary: In Janet Naakarley Amegatcher v. Attorney-General & Electoral Commission (Supreme Court, 2012), the plaintiff challenged the constitutionality of provisions in the Local Government Act, 1993 (Act 462) that empowered the President to unilaterally declare new districts and assign names via executive instrument. The Supreme Court held that Article 241(2) of the 1992 Constitution vests the power to redraw district boundaries or reconstitute districts exclusively in Parliament through legislation, not the President. The Court found Section 1(2) of Act 462 inconsistent with the Constitution and therefore void, emphasizing that district creation is a legislative function requiring parliamentary deliberation to prevent partisan abuse. The judgment reinforced constitutional limits on executive power and affirmed Parliamentâ€™s role in local government restructuring.
verdict: The Supreme Court declared Section 1(2) of the Local Government Act, 1993 (Act 462) unconstitutional and void for violating Articles 241(2) and 106(1) of the 1992 Constitution.
rationaleHighlights: Power to create districts constitutionally vested in Parliament, not President
Section 1(2) of Act 462 violates Article 241(2) and Article 106(1) of the 1992 Constitution
Historical constitutional trends support parliamentary role in district creation
Risk of partisan abuse justifies limiting presidential power
Electoral Commission's advisory role does not override constitutional framework
